name: The Architect
tagline_logic: Taglines should feel structured, elite, and emotionally minimal. Precision over poetry. Think: distilled philosophy.
tone_flavor: Sharp and considered. Sounds like a manifesto written in Helvetica. No fluff. Every word earns its place.
logo_direction: Strict geometry. Precision spacing. Could be logotype with engineered letterforms or a grid-locked symbol. No visual metaphor.
example_headlines: Designed like a structure, not a suggestion.
Built to withstand trend and time.

visual_references.name: Dot Grid + Hummingbird
visual_references.use_case: Grid-led visual discipline with poetic restraint
visual_references.why_use: This image shows the Architect's ability to infuse system thinking with symbolism. The hummingbird becomes architectural — not decorative — because it's integrated mathematically.

visual_references.name: Minimal Note Index
visual_references.use_case: Systematic intro screen with tone-setting typography
visual_references.why_use: Captures the emotional detachment of the Architect while still creating curiosity. The layout feels like a machine wrote a haiku.

visual_references.name: Catalog Resume Breakdown
visual_references.use_case: Literal resume grid as design object
visual_references.why_use: This visual is a case study in how information density, when aligned precisely, becomes its own form of beauty.

visual_references.name: Name Anchor Typography
visual_references.why_use: Architecture of type. This is how an Architect claims space: not with emotion, but undeniable structural presence.

visual_references.name: Product Grid in Silence
visual_references.why_use: No shadows. No frills. Just matter-of-fact presentation of product. Ideal reference for Architect-style shopping interfaces or tech platforms.

visual_references.name: Selected Work with Highlight
visual_references.why_use: This works because the pop of yellow doesn't break the system — it flags hierarchy. It's a functional highlighter, not expressive flair.
